concern:
hi all! i have accommodations at my college and if you don’t know about those you should!! i have a documented disability (mental health related) that states i need a few extra steps to make college life easier.



anyways, in order to put these into place you must visit your professor and discuss them with a letter from the coordinator and have them sign it, which i have done for all my classes except this one. last week was my first week back but i’m recovering from covid and the flu so i couldn’t attend but have went back yesterday. i attempted to find my professors office last week but had to go home from almost passing out and yesterday despite the posted hours, he wasn’t available in his office. so now i’m left with the biggest issue ever, how do i handle my preferential seating?!



usually i sit closest to the door because i tend to leave the class at times for movement or if something goes bad in my head, but yesterday made me realize i can’t just sit wherever.



i had talked to my professor before class and he let me know to sit wherever i need to so i did but i had a girl tell me i was in her spot and needed to move. there’s no assignees seating and i had gotten the go ahead from my prof but this still caught me off guard as i’m a very nervous person. i cant imagine telling someone they’re in my spot, and didn’t even do that in high school. there was a spot one over from me, and she ended up sitting in it anyways. i did let her know i have accommodations to sit where i need to and she walked away, but now i can’t say that because i haven’t talked to the prof.



we’re advised to only talk about accommodations outside of class and during office hours, but i’m getting extremely anxious for my class in two hours and my teacher only has office hours after. should i email? i know im not supposed to email about this but i’m not sure what to do when i’m told i’m in someone’s spot and i’m in the spot that works best for me. any advice? am i being dramatic? i want to say let’s all be adults but i’m the one refusing to get up from someone’s else’s spot lol

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to see you today. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks. I've been feeling really anxious about managing my accommodations in class, and it's stressing me out. It's like I'm stuck between following the rules and feeling comfortable.

It sounds like you're feeling torn between adhering to the rules and finding a level of comfort with your accommodations, which is understandably causing you stress. Can you tell me more about what's been happening with your classes?

client: Well, there was this whole situation where I needed to sit near the door for my mental health, but someone said I was in their spot. I had the professor's okay, but it still felt really awkward, and now I'm not sure how to handle it without my accommodations fully sorted.
It seems like you felt awkward and unsure about the situation even though you had your professor's approval to sit there. What thoughts or feelings have come up for you since then?

client: I've mostly been feeling anxious and worried that it'll happen again. I keep overthinking what I should do if someone else questions me, especially since my accommodations haven't been fully confirmed with the professor yet.
It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of uncertainty, and it's making you anxious about future situations. How do you ideally see things working out with your accommodations in class?

I just want everything to be sorted so I can focus on my studies without feeling stressed about where I sit. It would be great if I could just have that spot near the door without any issues or confrontations.
It sounds like having a stress-free learning environment is really important to you. What would it mean for you and your studies if these accommodations were fully in place?
If my accommodations were fully in place, I'd feel way more at ease and could concentrate better on my classes. It would take away a lot of the anxiety I have about attending.
Having your accommodations in place seems crucial for your peace of mind and focus in class. What other benefits do you imagine if you feel more at ease and concentrate better on your studies?
I'd probably be able to engage more in class discussions and absorb the material better. Plus, I wouldn't be constantly distracted by anxiety, so my grades might improve too.
It sounds like improving your grades and participation in class are important goals for you. How do you think achieving this could impact your overall college experience?
client: Honestly, it would make college a lot more enjoyable and less daunting. I'd feel more confident and probably even more motivated to pursue other opportunities or activities on campus.

Improving your college experience sounds like a valuable goal. Based on what you've shared, maybe we could explore steps for ensuring your accommodations are fully in place and identify any resources or campus services that might support you. What do you think?
client: Yeah, that sounds like a good idea. Having a plan could definitely ease some of my stress. I'm open to any suggestions or resources you think might help.

Based on what you mentioned, some options might include contacting the disability services office to ensure your accommodations are up and running or checking if there are study groups or workshops for extra support. Which of these might you like to start with, or is there another step you have in mind?

I think starting with the disability services office makes the most sense. Just making sure everything is in place officially would be a relief. Maybe after that, I can look into study groups if I feel like I need extra help.

That sounds like a solid plan. Reaching out to the disability services office is a great first step. How about we set a goal for when you might contact them, and then we can talk about how you can monitor the progress with your accommodations?
Yeah, setting a goal seems helpful. I can aim to contact them by the end of this week. It’d be nice to have some sort of check-in system to see how everything’s going with my accommodations.

Great, it sounds like you're on the right track. Your goal is to contact the disability services office by the end of this week to confirm your accommodations. This will help reduce your stress and give you peace of mind. As a coping strategy, consider keeping a journal to track your progress and feelings as things get sorted. For the next step, let's plan for a follow-up check-in next week to discuss how things are progressing and if you might need additional support or resources. You're taking proactive steps, and that's commendable. Keep it up!
That makes sense, and I’ll try keeping a journal, too. Let’s definitely have a check-in next week to see how things are going.
